Key Arguments: It is inconsistent with international human rights regarding freedom of speech.
It grants excessive power to unelected bureaucrats without transparency or accountability.
The definition of 'harm' is vague and could be used to suppress legitimate speech.
There is no liability for digital service providers for excessive policing of speech.
Government-authorized content is excluded, creating an unfair asymmetry.
ACMA is given excessive powers that breach privacy.
There is insufficient accountability and oversight for misuse of powers.
Provisions for freedom of expression are inadequate.
Penalties are excessive and could chill free speech.
Notable Quotes: The Bill is inconsistent with fundamental freedoms of speech and communication under international human rights instruments.
The Bill puts too much power in the hands of unelected bureaucrats to silence speech in the public square without transparency or accountability.
The severity of the penalties for failing to comply with the misinformation codes and standards... is excessive and will provide a ‘chilling effect’ on free speech.
